title: Quiz 2: Processes & Planning in Health Promotion
topicName: Principles & Practice of Health Promotion I
description: Test your ability to plan health promotion programs using the 6-step process and understand key focus areas.

questions.question: Reorder the Six Steps for Planning a Health Promotion Program correctly:
questions.explanation: 1. Manage -> 2. Assess -> 3. Goals -> 4. Strategies -> 5. Indicators -> 6. Review.
questions.hint: You must define the process before assessing the situation.

questions.question: In Step 2 (Situational Assessment), which question are you primarily trying to answer?

options.text: How much money do we have?
What is the situation and what is making it better or worse?
Who will be the project manager?

questions.explanation: Situational assessment involves identifying the current situation, influences (better/worse), and possible actions.
questions.hint: It is about diagnosing the current state.

questions.question: What specific term refers to a 'brief statement specifying the desired change caused by the program'?
questions.explanation: An outcome objective specifies the desired change caused by the program.

questions.question: Which of the following are recognized 'Focus Areas' of Health Promotion? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Health promotion focuses on Good Governance, Health Literacy, Healthy Settings, and Social Mobilization.
questions.hint: Think about broad societal influences, not clinical procedures.

questions.question: In the planning process, 'Indicators' are developed BEFORE identifying strategies and activities.
questions.explanation: False. Strategies and activities (Step 4) are identified before developing indicators (Step 5) to measure them.
questions.hint: You need to know WHAT you are doing before you can measure it.

questions.question: Match the Health Promotion Strategy with its description:

richContent.content:
StrategyExample
ScreeningBlood sugar testing
AdvocacyLobbying for policy

pairs.right: Improving knowledge and attitudes (e.g., audiovisual aids)
Empowering communities to control their health

questions.explanation: Screening targets individuals; Education targets knowledge; Action targets empowerment; Settings targets environment.
questions.hint: Match the activity to the level of intervention.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of an 'Outcome' of health promotion?
questions.explanation: Improved quality of life, reduced premature death, and improved health status are outcomes. The others are outputs or activities.
questions.hint: Outcome is the final result or benefit.

questions.question: A ___BLANK___ model is a graphic depiction of the relationship between all parts of a program (goals, objectives, strategies) used in Step 6 of planning.
questions.explanation: A logic model visually maps out the program components and their relationships.
questions.hint: It represents the 'logic' behind the program.

questions.question: What is the key purpose of 'Social Mobilization' as a focus area?

options.text: To bring together societal influences to raise awareness and demand for health care
To force people to visit the hospital
To reduce the number of health workers

questions.explanation: Social mobilization unites partners to raise awareness, demand, and resources for health.

questions.question: Which strategy involves 'speaking up for the voiceless' to gain political commitment?
questions.explanation: Advocacy is the act of arguing in favor of a cause, often representing those who cannot speak for themselves.
